topic: Socio Religious Reform Movement, Organisations and Personalities

flashcards.back: Syed Ahmad of Rai Bareilly (founder), Vilayet Ali, Shah Muhammad Hussain, Farhat Hussain, Inayat Ali (all from Patna). 1820s onwards
Rohilkhand, Kabul, NWFP, Bengal, Central Provinces
Inspired by Abdul Wahab (Arabia) and Shah Waliullah (1702-63)
Sought to revive authentic Islam and Arabian culture as it existed during Prophet's time.
Opposed Western influences on Islam, emphasised individual conscience in religious matters
Initially directed at Sikhs in Punjab, later shifted focus against British after annexation of Punjab (1849)
Played significant role in spreading anti-British sentiments and mobilising resistance
1831. Leader: Syed Mir Nisar Ali (Titu Mir), disciple of Syed Ahmad Barelvi, follower of Wahabism
Advocated implementation of Sharia principles in Bengal, organised Muslim peasants against Hindu landlords and British indigo planters
Movement led to confrontation with British police in 1831, which resulted in his death
Haji Shariatullah, 1818-19, later led by son Dudu Mian
Spread reinterpretation of Islam and eradicate un-Islamic practices, especially in East Bengal
After British conquest of region, transformed into revolutionary force.
Dudu Mian organised paramilitary force to challenge Hindu landlords and Indigo planters who exploited poor peasants
Dudu Mian developed structure from village level to provincial level, with khalifa (authorised deputies) overseeing each region
Movement led to rebellion against injustice, with swift reaction of landlords uprooting socio-economic foundation of region
Dacca, 1839. Leader: Karamat Ali Jaunpuri
Founded on teachings of Shah Waliullah
Stood in opposition to Faraizi Movement, offering more traditionalist religious stance without revolutionary and social reform goals that
raizi pursued
Calcutta, 1863. Leader: Abdul Latif
Promote modern education and scientific knowledge among Muslims. Eradicate social practices like polygamy among upper and middle-class Muslims
Played pivotal role in fostering Hindu-Muslim unity, aiming to bridge divides and promote social cohesion among different communities in Bengal
Saharanpur, UP, 1866. Muhammad Qasim Nanaytavi (1832-80) and Rashid Ahmad Gangohi (1828-1905)
Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, Mahmud-ul-Hasan, Shibli Numani
Revivalist movement focusing on Quranic teachings, rejecting Western education, advocating liberal interpretation of Islam.
Supported Indian National Congress, issued 1888 fatwa against Syed Ahmed Khan's associations
Mahmud-ul-Hasan fused Islamic principles with nationalism. Jamiat-ul-Ulema upheld Muslim rights.
Shibli Numani supported English, European sciences, and Hindu-Muslim unity
Syed Ahmed Khan (1817-98), 1875
Promoted religious reform through rational inquiry in religion, emphasising scientific and rational outlook.
Recognized value of Western education, aimed to socially reform Muslims. Played pivotal role in founding Scientific Society in 1864
Tahziz-al-Akhlaq (Urdu)
Mirza Ghulam Ahmad (1839-1908), 1889
Promoted human rights, tolerance, separation of mosque and state, opposed jihad, favoured Western education.
Mirza Ghulam Ahmad claimed to be Messiah, ending religious wars. Criticised for mystical elements, akin to Bahai faith
Ahmadiyya community is only Islamic sect that holds belief that Messiah has already arrived in form of Mirza Ghulam Ahmad

mcq.question: Wahabi Movement founder?
mcq.explanation: Syed Ahmad of Rai Bareilly founded Wahabi Movement in 1820s onwards.

mcq.question: Wahabi Movement was inspired by?
mcq.explanation: Wahabi Movement inspired by Abdul Wahab (Arabia) and Shah Waliullah (1702-63).

mcq.question: Wahabi initially directed at whom?
mcq.explanation: Wahabi initially directed at Sikhs in Punjab, later shifted focus against British after Punjab annexation (1849).

mcq.question: Titu Mir's Movement year?
mcq.explanation: Titu Mir's Movement was in 1831.

mcq.question: Titu Mir was disciple of?
mcq.explanation: Titu Mir (Syed Mir Nisar Ali) was disciple of Syed Ahmad Barelvi, follower of Wahabism.

mcq.question: Faraizi Movement founder?
mcq.explanation: Faraizi Movement founded by Haji Shariatullah in 1818-19, later led by son Dudu Mian.

mcq.question: Faraizi transformation in 1840?
mcq.explanation: After British conquest, Faraizi transformed into revolutionary force (1840). Dudu Mian organised paramilitary force against Hindu landlords and indigo planters.

mcq.question: Faraizi organisational structure?
options: Village to provincial level with khalifa deputies
mcq.explanation: Dudu Mian developed organisational structure from village to provincial level, with khalifa (authorised deputies) overseeing each region.

mcq.question: Taayuuni Movement leader?
mcq.explanation: Taayuuni Movement led by Karamat Ali Jaunpuri, Dacca, 1839.

mcq.question: Taayuuni vs Faraizi stance?
options: More traditionalist, opposed Faraizi revolutionary goals
mcq.explanation: Taayuuni offered more traditionalist religious stance without revolutionary/social reform goals that Faraizi pursued.

mcq.question: Mohammedan Literary Society founded?
mcq.explanation: Mohammedan Literary Society founded in 1863, Calcutta by Abdul Latif.

mcq.question: Mohammedan Literary Society aim?
options: Modern education, scientific knowledge, eradicate polygamy
mcq.explanation: Aimed to promote modern education/scientific knowledge among Muslims, eradicate social practices like polygamy.

mcq.question: Deoband School founded when/where?
mcq.explanation: Deoband School founded in 1866, Saharanpur, UP by Muhammad Qasim Nanaytavi and Rashid Ahmad Gangohi.

mcq.question: Deoband stance on Western education?
mcq.explanation: Deoband rejected Western education while advocating liberal interpretation of Islam.

mcq.question: Deoband issued fatwa (1888) against?
mcq.explanation: Deoband issued 1888 fatwa against Syed Ahmed Khan's associations.

mcq.question: Aligarh Movement founder?
mcq.explanation: Syed Ahmed Khan (1817-98) founded Aligarh Movement in 1875.

mcq.question: Aligarh founded Scientific Society in?
mcq.explanation: Aligarh Movement played pivotal role in founding Scientific Society in 1864.

mcq.question: Aligarh associated journal?
mcq.explanation: Aligarh Movement's associated journal: Tahziz-al-Akhlaq (Urdu).

mcq.question: Ahmadiyya Movement founder?
mcq.explanation: Mirza Ghulam Ahmad (1839-1908) founded Ahmadiyya Movement in 1889.

mcq.question: Ahmadiyya unique belief?
options: Messiah already arrived as Mirza Ghulam Ahmad
mcq.explanation: Ahmadiyya is only Islamic sect believing Messiah has already arrived in form of Mirza Ghulam Ahmad.
